metadata.title: High thermal insulation and compressive strength polypropylene foams fabricated by high-pressure foam injection molding and mold opening of nano-fibrillar composites

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Materials & Design
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/matdes
High thermal insulation and compressive strength polypropylene foams fabricated by high-pressure foam injection molding and mold opening of nano-fibrillar composites
Jinchuan Zhaoa,c, Qingliang Zhaoa, Chongda Wangc, Bing Guoa,⁎, Chul B. Parkc,⁎, Guilong Wangb,c,⁎
a Centre for Precision Engineering, School of Mechatronics Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150001, China b Key Laboratory for Liquid-Solid Structural Evolution and Processing of Materials (Ministry of Education), Shandong University, Jinan, Shandong 250061, China c Microcellular Plastics Manufacturing Laboratory, Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, University of Toronto, Toronto, Ontario M5S 3G8, Canada
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Foam injection molding Mold-opening Polypropylene PTFE fibrils Thermal insulation Compressive strength
A B S T R A C T
Polypropylene (PP) foams with a thermal conductivity of as low as 36.5 mW m−1 K−1 are fabricated by highpressure foam injection molding followed by mold-opening with CO2 as a blowing agent. Regular PPs are not suitable for foaming due to their poor melt strength. To improve melt strength, the in-situ fibrillated blends of PP/polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) are prepared using a regular co-rotating twin-screw extruder. The micromorphology characterized by SEM shows that fibrillated nanoscale PTFE fibers disperse very well in PP matrix. The DSC, dynamic shear rheology, and extensional rheology measurements demonstrate that the in-situ fibrillated PTFE fibers can significantly improve crystallization, visco-elastic performance, and strain-hardening behaviors, respectively. All these factors confirm that PTFE fibers are very effective to improve melt strength and thus foaming ability of PP. The foam injection molding results show that the PP foam's cell size reduces by nearly one order of magnitude while its expansion ratio increases by approximately three times in presence of PTFE fibers. Compared to PP foams, PP/PTFE foams show significantly improved thermal insulation performance due to the increased expansion ratio, as well as unique cell wall structures with micro-holes and/or nano-fibrils. Moreover, it demonstrates that smaller cell size leads to improved compressive strength.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In recent decades, world energy consumption has increased more than two times from 1973 to 2014 [1], where the share of total world energy production from fossil fuels is up to 81.4%. The burning of fossil fuels releases billions of polluting emissions, damaging the environment [2]. Renewable energy is an efficient solution to the pollution, but it contributes only 19.2% to the global energy consumption reported by REN21 of 2016 [3]. In this context, energy conservation through enhancing energy efficiency shows great potential to achieve global energy sustainability. Thermal insulation materials play a pivotal role in energy conservation [4], of which the most commonly used ones are mineral wools, fibreglass, cellulose, and polymeric foams. These common insulation materials present a typical thermal conductivity of higher than 35 mW m−1 K−1 in the absence of special insulation gas at standard conditions. Although silica-based aerogels exhibit much better thermal insulation performance than common insulation materials, their application are still very limited due to high cost, difficulty of
processing, intrinsic brittle feature, as well as toxic substances involved in their fabrication procedures [5].
Among common insulation materials, polymeric foams currently ranking second wide applications exhibit many superior properties, such as better insulation, easier handling and installing, lower cost, and no water absorption [5–8]. General technologies to fabricate polymeric foams include batch foaming, bead foaming, foam extrusion, and foam injection molding. Among these technologies, foam injection molding introduces several advantages, such as a shorter cycle time, less material usage, greater dimensional stability, and lower energy consumption [9]. Moreover, it has potential to produce porous products with improved mechanical properties. However, the traditional foam injection molding process can only produce foams with small expansion ratios, typically< 1.5-fold [9–11]. To achieve excellent thermal insulation foams, a large expansion ratio is essential to minimize the heat transfer contributed by solid conduction [12]. To increase the foam's expansion ratio, high-pressure foam injection molding [13,14] with mold-opening was developed [15–17], which can not only increase

expansion ratios but also improve mechanical performances including fracture toughness, impact and compressive strength [18,19].
Polypropylene (PP), a common semi-crystalline polymer, has become the second most important plastic with a global market share up to 19% by 2020 [20], due to its superior robustness to chemical and moisture attack, mechanical performance, manufacturability, recyclability, and versatile applications. In particular, foamed PP exhibits remarkable impact strength and toughness, durability, and strength to weight ratio [21,22]. Due to its unique and advantageous characteristics, PP is an ideal candidate to prepare high-performance thermal insulation foams combined with excellent mechanical properties. However, pure PP generally exhibits low melt strength and weak strain-hardening behavior due to its linear structure of molecules as well as the crystalline phase [23,24], which leads to a poor foaming ability. One solution is to modify the polymer chain by cross-linking or long-chain branching, which can remarkably enhance the strain-hardening response yet accompanying with high cost of manufacture [25,26]. Another solution is to improve crystallization using nucleating agents because crystallization helps to improve the melt strength and thus foaming ability of PP. A variety of nucleating agents such as nano-/ micron-sized talc [27], clay [28,29], and silica [30,31], as well as fibrils (e.g. cellulosic fibrils [32], and polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) fibrils [33]) have exhibited excellent potential on improving PP's crystallization and hence foaming ability. Rizvi et al. [34,35] have revealed that PTFE fibrils can dramatically increase the bubble density of PP foam by up to three orders of magnitude in foam extrusion process. The mechanism is that the in-situ fibrillated PTFE fibrils create physical networks of entanglements in PP matrix, resulting in significantly enhanced strain-hardening behavior and melt strength. However, to the best of our knowledge, there is few studies involving the PP/PTFE's foaming behavior in high-pressure foam injection molding with mold opening.
In this study, the in-situ fibrillation process based on a twin-screw compounding was conducted to prepare nano-fibrillar PP/PTFE composite with improved melt strength and foaming ability. To clarify PTFE fibrils' role in the crystallization behavior of PP, the non-isothermal crystallization of PP and PP/PTFE composites were investigated by a differential scanning calorimeter (DSC). Furthermore, the dynamic frequency sweep tests, dynamic temperature sweep tests, and extensional viscosity tests were implemented using a rheometer to study the effect of PTFE fibrils on the rheological performance of PP melt. Moreover, thermal conductivity and compressive strength were measured to evaluate the performance of PP/PTFE foams prepared for thermal insulation applications. The mechanisms of cellular structure's effect on thermal conductivity and compressive strength were discussed. The prepared PP foams showed excellent thermal insulation performance with a thermal conductivity of as low as 36.5 mW m−1 K−1.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials and sample preparation
sections.text:
The polymer used was a linear isotactic polypropylene (Novatec-PP FY4), a commercial homo-polymer supplied by Japan Polypropylene Corporation, with a MFR of 5 g/10 min (at 230 °C/2.16 kg load). Polytetrafluoroethylene powders, Metablen-PTFE A-3000, were supplied by Mitsubishi Rayon. The blowing agent used was supercritical CO2 with a purity of higher than 99%, which was purchased from Linde Gas Inc.
Four PP blends with various PTFE weight concentrations of 100/0, 99/1, 97/3, and 95/5 were prepared. A co-rotational twin-screw extruder, manufactured by Toshiba Machine Co. Ltd. (Trade name: TEM-26SS), was used for compounding. The temperatures from the hopper zone to the die were set to be 50 °C, 160 °C, 180 °C, 200 °C, 200 °C, 200 °C, 200 °C, 200 °C, 200 °C, 200 °C, and 190 °C, respectively,
as shown in Fig. S1 of the supporting information. Compounding run at a discharge rate and a screw speed of 20 kg/h and 200 rpm, respectively.
To prepare samples for dynamic frequency sweep tests and dynamic temperature step tests, PP/PTFE composites in pellet forms were molded to round plates (i.e., Φ25 mm× 1.2 mm) by hot compression. To prepare samples for extensional viscosity tests, the composites were molded to rectangle shapes (i.e., 10 mm× 18 mm× 0.7 mm), with a duration of 4 min at 180 °C.

sections.heading: 2.2. PP/PTFE blends morphology characterization
sections.text: A scanning electron microscope (SEM, JEOL 6060) was used to characterize the morphology of PP/PTFE composites. To observe the morphology and dispersion of PTFE fibrils, the sample was cryogenically fractured in liquid nitrogen, and the fracture section was then exposed to the xylene bath for 2 min at 130 °C. Since xylene can dissolve the PP matrix while preserve PTFE fibrils which can thus be observed clearly. Thereafter, the samples were dried after being cleaned by acetone. Finally, the etched section was coated with a 10–20 nm layer of platinum using a sputter coater for SEM observation. The SEM images were analyzed to acquire the cellular structure information of foams using the software, Image J.

sections.heading: 2.3. DSC characterization
sections.text: A differential scanning calorimeter (DSC-Q2000, TA instruments), was used to measure the endothermic peak caused by crystal dissolution, for investigating the crystallization processes of the PP/PTFE blends. In a typical measurement, a small amount of material (around 10 mg) was first packaged with an aluminium pan and cap, and then put into a chamber filled with nitrogen. First, the blend was heated from 25 °C to 230 °C at 10 °C/min, and kept in the isothermal condition of 230 °C for 5 min, to eliminate the thermal history of the blends. After that, the melt was cooled to 25 °C at 10 °C/min, and thereafter heated to 230 °C again at 10 °C/min, to attain the thermal properties of the blends. To finish the measurement, the blend was cooled to 25 °C at 25 °C/min.

sections.heading: 2.4. Rheological characterizations
sections.text:
The dynamic frequency sweep experiments were conducted using a rotational rheometer, ARES, TA Instruments, to characterize the rheology behaviors of PP and PP/PTFE composites. To identify the strain limits of the linear viscoelastic regions, all dynamic strain sweep tests were implemented at a pre-set strain of 1% over a frequency range from 0.1 rad/s to 100 rad/s at 190 °C. The dynamic temperature step tests were also conducted to analyze the rheological behavior of blends as the temperature decreased from 220 °C to 100 °C at 2 °C/min with a frequency of 0.63 rad/s.
Extensional viscosity of the PP/PTFE blends was conducted using the same rheometer equipment (ARES, TA Instruments) to examine whether the strain-hardening behavior occurs in the presence of PTFE fibrils. In measurement, the extension rate was set at three levels: 0.01 s−1, 0.1 s−1, and 1 s−1, and the temperature selected was 170 °C. For each condition, experiments were repeated by at least three times, and the average values were reported.

sections.heading: 2.5. Mold-opening process and conditions
sections.text:
A 50-ton Arburg Allrounder 270 injection molding machine, equipped with a Mucell SCF delivery system (Trexel Inc., Massachusetts), was used in experiments. The mold used was a twoplate one with a fan gate and a rectangular mold cavity (132 mm 108 mm× 3.2 mm). Fig. 1 illustrates the schematic of MOFIM procedures. First, polymer/gas solution in barrel is injected to fill mold
cavity. Second, as the mold cavity is fully filled, a high packing pressure is maintained for a certain of dwelling time to compress the cells formed in filling stage back into polymer melt. Third, the injection mold is opened to trigger foaming. Finally, foam's cellular structure is stabilized by cooling. CO2 was pressurized to 24 MPa at the delivery system and injected into the barrel of the machine at 8 wt% of the molten PP. The temperatures of melt and mold were kept at 220 °C and 80 °C, respectively. The injection speed was 100 cm3/s. and the shot size was 60 cm3. The packing pressure was set to 30 MPa. The values of dwelling time were set to be 32.5 s, 35 s, 37.5 s, and 40 s, respectively. The values of mold-opening distance were set to be 12 mm, 15 mm, 18 mm, 21 mm, and 24 mm, respectively. The high packing pressure was used to extinguish the bubbles formed in the filling stage. The dwelling (packing) time directly influences the temperature and crystallization behavior of the melt while the mold-opening distance impacts the cell growth significantly, which are the reasons for choosing the dwelling time and mold-opening distance as variables.

sections.heading: 2.6. Foam characterization
sections.text:
A water displacement method (ASTM D792-00) was used to measure the density of the PP/PTFE blends and foamed samples, and the foam's expansion ratio (ϕ) is the density ratio of foams to blends. It should be noted that the solid skins of the samples were removed before the measurement. The cell size was measured based on the SEM micrographs, and at least 100 cells were measured for each case to obtain the average cell size. The cell nucleation density (Nn) was calculated as follows [12]:

sections.heading: 2.7. Thermal insulation characterization
sections.text:
A transient plane source hot disk thermal constant analyzer (TPS 2500, Them Test Inc., Sweden) was used to measure the thermal conductivity of the solid and foamed samples [36,37]. In a standard measurement, a round planar sensor made of a double spiral nickel foil, acting simultaneously as a heating device and as a temperature sensor, is first placed between two pieces of the sample. Afterwards, current power is supplied to the sensor for step-wise heating of the sample. During heating, the sensor can record its temperature response as a function of time. Based on the recorded temperature response curve, the sample's thermal conductivity can be derived by using the built-in Hot Disk Thermal Analyser software. The diameters of the sensor and sample were 4 mm and 20 mm, respectively, and the samples was measured at room temperature (23 ± 2 °C). The power output and test
duration were set at 0.005 W and 10 s, respectively. At least three specimens were measured for each condition, and the average value was recorded.

sections.heading: 2.8. Mechanical properties
sections.text: A computer controlled Instron mechanical system (INSTRON 2710- 102) was used to investigate the compressive strength of the PP/PTFE foams, according to ASTM D1621-2010. Cubic samples with a side length of 15 mm, which were cut from the fabricated PP/PTFE foam, were used for compression testing. The compression speed used in measurement was 1.5 mm/min. For each case, at least three samples were tested and the average value was reported.

sections.heading: 3.1. Fibrillated PP/PTFE blends
sections.text: Fig. 2 shows the cryo-fractured surface of PP with 5 wt% of PTFE after xylene etched. It can be found that the reticular fibrillated PTFE dispersed uniformly in the PP matrix. The average diameter of the PTFE fibril was around 300 nm. It is believed the reticular PTFE fibrils could dramatically improve the melt strength of PP. Yamaguchi et al. investigated the mechanism of fibrillation of solid PTFE in PP melt [33] and, furthermore, Rizvi et al. achieved similar interdigitated networks of PTFE fibrils for improving the foaming ability of PP in extrusion foaming process [34,35].

sections.heading: 3.2. Crystallization behavior of the PP/PTFE blends
sections.text: Fig. 3 shows the non-isothermal crystallization behavior of PP and PP/PTFE blends as a function of PTFE content at cooling/heating trace of DSC. It is observed from Fig. 3a that the addition of PTFE fibrils promoted a remarkable shift of crystallization peak to the higher temperature, which clearly demonstrated that PTFE fibrils can promote crystallization significantly due to their heterogeneous nucleation. In the heating graphs as Fig. 3b shows, the peak of melting temperature of PP/PTFE blends is higher than that of PP, indicating that PTFE fibrils improved the quality of crystalline structure, such as quantity, size, and distribution [38–40]. In order to quantitatively estimate the effect of PTFE fibrils on the crystallization behavior of PP, the key parameters from DSC scans were summarized in Table 1. We noticed that the crystallization peak was increased by> 10 °C, the melting temperature was increased by 1.5–3 °C, and the degree of crystallinity was increased from 36.14% to 40.18% in the presence of PTFE fibrils. All of these factors clearly demonstrate that FTFE fibrils are very effective heterogeneous nucleating agents in promoting crystallization of the PP matrix.

sections.heading: 3.3. Rheological behavior of the PP/PTFE blends
sections.text:
The rheological behavior of material plays a critical role in both bubble nucleation and growth of the foaming process. The melt linear viscoelastic responses of PP and its blends were characterized to investigate the effect of PTFE fibrils on the rheological behavior. Fig. 4 plots the storage (G′) and loss (G″) modulus, complex viscosity (η*), and tangent of the phase angle shift (tan δ) against frequency (ω) for PP and its blends, respectively. It is observed that G′ and G″ increased at different PTFE concentrations as ω increasing from 0.1 rad/s to 100 rad/s in Fig. 4a–b. Furthermore, the increments of G′ and G″ at low frequencies (< 1 rad/s) were larger than that at high frequencies (> 100 rad/s), which was resulted from the constraint generated by the spatially linked structure at low frequency [41–43]. Besides, increasing the fibril concentration resulted in a gradual increase of both G′ and G″, due to the increase of characteristic relaxation time with the fiber concentration [44,45]. The longer
characteristic relaxation time is available to generate higher local stress for cell nucleation in the foaming process [21]. As Fig. 4c shows, η* values decreased with the increase of ω, since the increasing frequency aligned the fibrils preferentially along the shear direction, thereby decreasing the viscosity. The observation that η* values increased with an increase in the PTFE concentration, indicates the formation of PTFEfibril network structure and its ability to improve the viscosity, especially at a low frequency. Fig. 4d plots the loss tangent, tan δ, to characterize the elastic response of the polymer melt. The tan δ values decreased with an increase in the fibril concentration, showing a lower viscous/elastic ratio as the fibril concentration was increased. At high PTFE-fibril concentrations (over 3 wt%), the value of tan δ became almost independent of the frequency, attributing to the network structure formed by fibril-fibril interactions (shown as Fig. 3) and/or fibril-polymer chain interactions [42,45].
To characterize the viscoelastic response in the extension flow, the growth curves of uniaxial extensional viscosity (ηE+) over various strain rates were measured at 170 °C shown as Fig. 5. The transient extensional viscosity, ηE+, described as the tensile-stress growth coefficient, is related with the tensile stress growth function (σ t ε( , )̇E+ ) and extensional strain rate (ε)̇ illustrated as Eq. (2)

It is obvious from Fig. 5 that the addition of PTFE fibrils improved the extensional viscosity by nearly one order of magnitude. Furthermore, PTFE fibrils also effectively enhanced the strain hardening response for the PP matrix over the applied strain rates, including 1 s−1, 0.1 s−1, and 0.01 s−1. This enhancement in extensional viscosity and strain hardening is attributed to the physical network formed by the flexible PTFE fibrils [33,34], as illustrated by the SEM micrograph in Fig. 2 and the platform-shaped curve in Fig. 4d. Besides, the degree of strain hardening depended upon the applied strain rate, showing as the larger the strain rate, the higher the degree of strain hardening. The origin of the strain hardening behavior depending on the strain rates is that strain hardening generally relates to the inability of the macromolecules to disentangle quickly enough and follow the deformation [46–49].
As for semi-crystal polymers, temperature critically influences the rheological properties due to the rapid change in viscosity as the crystallization behavior occurs. To investigate the rheological properties of blends as a function of temperature, dynamic temperature step tests were carried out with temperature decreasing from 220 °C to 120 °C at 2 °C/min, and the complex viscosity (η*) was illustrated in Fig. 6. η* increased with the decrease of temperature, and a rapid increase of η* occurred at a temperature lower than the crystallization temperature owing to the formation of interlaced crystals during the crystallization process. Moreover, the PTFE fibrils effectively improved the crystallization temperature η* over all the applied temperature. The
higher the PTFE concentration was, the larger the η* value was, which was consequent with the DSC and rheological results in Fig. 3 and Fig. 4c, respectively.

sections.heading: 3.4. Foaming behavior and cellular morphology
sections.text:
Fig. 7 shows a schematic view of the injection molding product, including the basic size, the typical morphological structure of injection-molded foams, and the method to prepare samples for the SEM observation in two different sections, perpendicular and parallel to the mold-opening direction. Note that the cells were clearly stretched in the mold-opening direction, compared with that in the direction perpendicular to mold opening, and a classical sandwich structure was generated in the mold-opening direction. The cell structures in the subsequent characterization were all in the section perpendicular to the mold-opening direction.
To investigate the effect of dwelling time as well as the in-situ fibrillated PTFE fibrils on the foaming behavior of PP matrix, the MOFIM experiments were carried out for the PP blends with four different concentrations of PTFE. Fig. 8 illustrates the SEM micrographs of the foams fabricated with MOFIM by changing the dwelling time from 25 s to 45 s and setting the mold-opening distance to 12 mm (expansion ratio was around 8-fold). Obviously, when the dwelling time was 25 s, there is no foam obtained between the solid skins, a hollow balloon-like sample as shown in the first row of Fig. 8. At early dwelling times (< 25 s), the melt temperature was relatively higher [17], and hence, the melt strength was too weak to withstand the biaxial or uniaxial stretch due to bubble growth because there were few crystals foamed in the high temperature PP matrix. With an increase in the dwelling time, well foamed samples were achieved as in the middle region of Fig. 8, resulting from the increased crystals which improved the melt strength and accordingly enhanced the foaming ability of PP matrix. Furthermore, it can be deduced that the PTFE fibrils improve the melt strength of PP mainly by perfecting its crystallization behavior, rather than the self-structure of fibrils. However, when the dwelling time was excessively longer (> 45 s), the superabundant crystals foamed network structure, significantly enhancing the rigidity of the PP melt, which greatly suppressed cell nucleation and growth, and thus,
partly foamed samples was attained in the last row of Fig. 8. Besides, it is also noticed that the addition of PTFE fibrils effectively decreased the cell size. With an increase in the PTFE concentration, the cell size also had a tendency to decrease. The decreased cell size was owing to the effect of PTFE fibrils on the crystallization and rheological behavior, which can be verified by the results of DSC and rheological tests.
To quantitatively analyze the role of dwelling time in promoting foaming ability of PP matrix, the average cell sizes and cell nucleation densities in the section which is perpendicular to the mold-opening direction were calculated based on the SEM micrographs. Fig. 9a plots the cell sizes of PP and PP/PTFE blends as a function of the dwelling time, where the aspect ratio is around 3 which is the ratio of the cell diameter in the mold-opening direction to that in its perpendicular section. The cell size decreased with an increased dwelling time over different concentrations of PTFE. By adding only 1% PTFE, the cell sizes decreased by one order of magnitude, from around 600 μm to 60 μm, and as the PTFE concentration increased, the cell sizes further decreased from 60 μm to 30 μm. PTFE fibrils dramatically promoted
the crystallization kinetics of the PP matrix, i.e., melt strength, and a higher PTFE concentration more effectively influenced the crystallinity by supplying more crystal nucleation agents [34], corresponding with the DSC results. Furthermore, we noticed that the cell size with a high PTFE concentration was more sensitive to dwelling time than that with a low PTFE concentration, which was illustrated by the variation tendency of cell sizes with PTFE concentration varying from 1 wt% to 5 wt% (Fig. 9a). It indicated that the variation of melt temperature by changing dwelling time, impacted more significantly on melt strength of the blend with high-concentration PTFE than that with lowconcentration PTFE, resulting from the stronger interaction of higher crystalline blends [33].
Fig. 9b shows the foam cell nucleation densities of PP and PP/PTFE blends corresponding to different dwelling times. The cell nucleation densities increased gradually with an increase in the dwelling time. Notably, by blending PTFE into PP, the cell densities were dramatically increased by three orders of magnitude, from 104 cells/cm3 to 107 cells/ cm3. As the PTFE concentration increases from 1 wt% to 5 wt%, the cell
densities were increased from 107 cells/cm3 to 109 cells/cm3. Besides, the cell densities of PP/PTFE foams also presented sensitivity to dwelling time, and the larger the PTFE concentration was, the higher the sensitivity was. The addition of PTFE promoted the crystallinity and melt strength, and thus, improved the cell nucleation and simultaneously suppressed the collapse and coalescence of cells, leading to the significant enhancement of cellular morphology [33,34].
To further increase the expansion ratio, the experiments with larger mold-opening distances were carried out using pure PP and PP blends with 5 wt% PTFE. It is found that the expansion ratio of PP foams cannot increase further with the mold-opening distance, the maximum expansion ratio that can be achieved for pure PP foam was< 10-fold. In contrast, the maximum expansion ratio that can be achieved for PP/ PTFE blend can be higher than 18-fold. The results could be explained by the effect of PTFE fibrils on foaming ability as follows. PTFE efficiently improved the crystallinity and visco-elastic properties severally confirmed by Fig. 4 and Fig. 5–7, and thus promoted the cell heterogenous nucleation and suppressed the collapse and coalescence of cells. Furthermore, the enhanced melt strength reduced the loss of gas, leading to the improvement of expansion by supplying sufficient gas.
To study the role of the mold-opening distance on the cellular morphology, Fig. 10a–b plot the cell sizes and cell densities of PP blends with 5 wt% PTFE over different mold-opening distances, respectively. The cell sizes and cell densities had been kept almost constant around a value with an increased mold-opening distance over different dwelling times. To clarify their correlation, SEM micrographs were detected in two directions: parallel (Fig. 11a–c) and perpendicular (Fig. 11d–f) to the mold-opening direction. We noticed that as the mold-opening distance increases, cells were significantly stretched along the moldopening direction (Fig. 11a–c). However, the cell structures in the section perpendicular to the mold-opening direction were almost the same, Fig. 11d–f show.
It is also observed from Fig. 10a that cell size first decreased and then increased with the increase of dwelling time regardless of the mold-opening distance. We noticed that the optimum dwelling time was 37.5 s, which decreased the cell sizes by> 40%, from around 35 μm to< 20 μm. The reason for existing this optimum dwelling time could be explained from the crystallization's role in cell nucleation. A longer dwelling time can reduce the melt temperature and produce more crystals, both of which help to improve the melt strength, thus producing more cells with smaller sizes. However, excessively high crystallinity could generate high-stiffness melt, which could be harmful for cell nucleation due to the increased energy barrier [21].

sections.heading: 3.5. Thermal property characterization of PP and PP/PTFE foams
sections.text:
To investigate the thermal insulation properties of the prepared PP and PP/PTFE (5 wt%) foams, their thermal conductivities were measured using the TPS technique. Fig. 12 shows the variation of the thermal conductivity of the PP foams and the PP/PTFE foams as a function of the expansion ratio. The thermal conductivity gradually decreased with an increase in the expansion ratio for both PP and PP/ PTFE foams. The minimum thermal conductivity of the PP foam was about 60 mWm−1 K−1 corresponding to the maximum expansion ratio of 10-fold while the minimum thermal conductivity of the PP/PTFE foam was as small as 36.5 mW m−1 K−1 corresponding to the maximum expansion ratio of 18-fold. The dramatically enhanced thermal insulation property of the PP/PTFE foams should be mainly owing to its significantly increased expansion ratio. Notably, PP/PTFE foams had much smaller thermal conductivity than the PP foams even under the same expansion ratio. It means that the increased expansion ratio was not the only reason leading to the improved thermal insulation property of the PP/PTFE foams. It is observed from Fig. 12 that a longer dwelling benefited the thermal insulation property of the PP/PTFE foams.
For better understanding the measured thermal conductivity of the
PP foams and the PP/PTFE foams, a classical theoretical model was employed to quantitatively model the heat transfer through the polymer foams. Basically, conduction, convection, and radiation are the three fundamental modes of heat transfer. Heat transfer through foams consists of four contributions, and the total thermal conductivity, λtot, can be expressed as follows [50]:
λ λ λ λ λ= + + +tot gas sol rad con (3)
where λgas, λsol are the thermal conductivities contributed by the gas phase and the polymer phase in the heat transfer mode of thermal
conduction, which are proportional to their respective volume fraction in the polymer foams. λrad is the equivalent thermal conductivity contributed by thermal radiation. λcon is the equivalent thermal conductivity contributed by thermal convection. Owing to the restraint of gas movement inside< 4 mm cells, the convection could be disregarded [51]. Accordingly, Eq. (3) can be rewritten as follows:
λ k V ζk V λ= + +tot gas gas sol sol rad (4)
where Vgas and Vsol are the volume fraction of the air phase and polymer phase in the foams, respectively. ζ is a parameter related to the inherent tortuosity of the cell structure, which can be assumed that ζ = 1 to reduce Eq. (4) to the simple mixture rule [13]. kgas is the air's thermal conductivity which is around 26 mWm−1 K−1 at the standard conditions, and ksol is the polymer's thermal conductivity which is 231 mWm−1 K−1 measured by TPS. Notably, PTFE fibers show very little effect on the thermal conductivity of PP (Fig. S2 in the Supporting information).
Since the foam's expansion ratio is not large, the total thermal conductivity is mainly contributed by the thermal conduction of the polymer phase due to the relatively small gaseous thermal conduction and simultaneously the weak thermal radiation [50]. In this situation, it will be very effective to reduce the foam's total thermal conductivity by increasing the foam's expansion ratio due to the reduced thermal conductivity contributed by the polymer phase. Because the PP/PTFE foam can have larger expansion ratios than the PP foam, the former one should therefore exhibit much better thermal insulation property than the later one (Fig. 12). It is also noticed that the PTFE fibers can not only increase the expansion ratio but also opening in the cell walls.
Fig. 13 shows the typical cellular structure of the PP/PTFE foams. It can be clearly observed that there were a mass of micro-holes and micro/ nano fibrils in the cell walls. Such micro/nano structures in the cell wall destroyed the continuity of the polymer matrix, significantly increased the tortuosity of the heat transfer path, and also increased the phonon scattering at the nano structure boundaries [50]. Thus, they could increase the thermal resistance and hence reduce the thermal conductivity. This should be the main reason why PP/PTFE foams had much smaller thermal conductivities than the PP foams even if they had the same expansion ratio (Fig. 12). With an increase in the dwelling time from 35 s to 40 s, it is observed that there were more open cells with micro/nano holes and fibrils (Fig. 13). This can be used to explain the improved thermal insulation property of the PP/PTFE foams with a longer dwelling time. Moreover, the PTFE fibers can also significantly reduce the foam's cell size and hence increase the number of cell walls. The increased cell walls can block more thermal radiations [52], which also contributed to the smaller thermal conductivity of the PP/PTFE foams.

sections.heading: 3.6. Compressive strength characterization of PP/PTFE foams
sections.text:
The compression tests were conducted to investigate the effect of the cellular morphology on the prepared PP/PTFE (5 wt%) foams' mechanical properties. Fig. 14a shows the stress-strain curves of the PP/PTFE foams with various expansion ratios. It clearly demonstrates that the foam's compression modulus as well as the compressive strength reduced gradually with an increase in the expansion ratio. Fig. 14b plots the dependence of the compressive strength on the expansion ratio. The compressive strength reduced significantly with an increase in the expansion ratio but the reducing rate became slower. As the expansion ratio increased from 8-fold to 18-fold with an increment by 2.25 times, the compressive strength dramatically decreased from 1.2 MPa to< 0.2 MPa with an decrement by> 6 times. Fig. 14c shows the stress-strain curves of the PP/PTFE foams with a constant expansion
ratio of 8-fold. It clearly indicates that a smaller cell size helped to increase the foam's compression modulus and strength. Fig. 14d plots the correlation between the cell size and the compressive strength. It is observed that the compressive strength nearly increased linearly with the decrease of the cell size in the research scope. Specifically, the compressive strength increased from 0.81 MPa to 1.24 MPa with an increment by 53.1% as the cell size reduced from 50 μm to 38 μm.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
PP foams with thermal conductivity of as low as 36.5 mW m−1 K−1 were fabricated by mold-opening foam injection molding with CO2 as the blowing agent, combining in situ fibrillation of PTFE in PP matrix to improve melt strength. The fibrillar morphology, crystallinity, rheological properties, cellular morphology, thermal insulation and mechanical properties were characterized. The correlation between cellular structure and the performance of PP/PTFE composite foams were clarified.
The fibrillated PTFE fibrils improved the cell morphology dramatically by enhancing the melt strength, strain hardening behavior, and crystallinity of PP due to their sub-micro fibrillar structure and good dispersion in the matrix, which was represented as the remarkable drop of the cell size by 30 times, from 600 μm to 20 μm, and the enhancement of the expansion ratio from 10-fold to around 20-fold, up to 2 times.
The PP/PTFE foams exhibited lower thermal conductivity than PP foams. The improved thermal insulation property was majorly owing to the dramatic increase of the expansion ratio. Moreover, PTFE caused the formation of micro-holes and/or nanoscale fibrils in cell walls, which further decreased the thermal conductivity due to phonon scattering effect. Furthermore, PTFE significantly increased the quantity of cell walls, which could block more thermal radiation, and thus contributed to reducing the thermal conductivity.
As expected, the compressive strength of polymer foams reduces significantly with the increase of expansion ratio. Reducing cell size led to improved compressive strength of polymer foams because of the reduced bending moment.

metadata.abstractText: Polypropylene (PP) foams with a thermal conductivity of as low as 36.5 mW m K are fabricated by highpressure foam injection molding followed by mold-opening with CO2 as a blowing agent. Regular PPs are not suitable for foaming due to their poor melt strength. To improve melt strength, the in-situ fibrillated blends of PP/polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) are prepared using a regular co-rotating twin-screw extruder. The micromorphology characterized by SEM shows that fibrillated nanoscale PTFE fibers disperse very well in PP matrix. The DSC, dynamic shear rheology, and extensional rheology measurements demonstrate that the in-situ fibrillated PTFE fibers can significantly improve crystallization, visco-elastic performance, and strain-hardening behaviors, respectively. All these factors confirm that PTFE fibers are very effective to improve melt strength and thus foaming ability of PP. The foam injection molding results show that the PP foam's cell size reduces by nearly one order of magnitude while its expansion ratio increases by approximately three times in presence of PTFE fibers. Compared to PP foams, PP/PTFE foams show significantly improved thermal insulation performance due to the increased expansion ratio, as well as unique cell wall structures with micro-holes and/or nano-fibrils. Moreover, it demonstrates that smaller cell size leads to improved compressive strength.
